Current events must render evident to all Marylanders the necessity of enrolling themselves at once to effect such an organization, and there should be no delay.
I can be seen daily at No. 15 Pearl street from 10 A. M. to 2 P. M.
div3.closer:
Frank X. Ward,
Late Adjutant of 1st Md. Regiment.
au 18--12t*

div3.head: Camp of 1st Reg't Va. Artillery, near Petersburg, Aug. 14, 1862.
div3.p:
Those members of the 2d company Richmond Howitzers, who are detailed from the company, and are from the city of Richmond, are hereby informed that I hold subject to their order fifteen dollars for each man, being money appropriated by the city of Richmond for the benefit of the volunteers from that city.
My address, for the present, is Petersburg, Va.
div3.closer:
David Watson,
Capt. Comd'g 2d Co. Richmond Howitzers.
au 18--6t*

div3.head: Marylanders
div3.p: wishing to join the Chesapeake Artillery, composed entirely of citizens of Maryland, will address the undersigned at Gordonsville, care of Major A. R. Courtney, Chief of Artillery, Gen. Ewell's division.--Two Parrot guns have just been added to the battery, making it one of the best in the service, and I am desirous to increase the membership of the company accordingly.
div3.closer:
W. D. Brown,
au 18--10t* Captain Commanding.

div3.p: The Paroled members of the Richmond Light infantry Blues, will meet on Monday evening next, 18th instant, at 5 P. M., at Hewitt & Lawrence's shop, next to Post- Office, on Bank street.
div3.closer:
Fred. Carter,
au 18--1t* C. P. Bigger.

div3.head: Headqr's 1st Reg't Va. Artillery. near Petersburg, Aug. 16, 1862.
div3.p:
All Absentees from this company will report at camp, near Petersburg, immediately.
Those absent from sickness will send Surgeon's certificates.
div3.closer:
B. H. Smith, Jr.,
au 18--3t* Captain 3d Howitzer Co.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--About the 20th of July, from the subscriber, a negro man, named John Kemp.
He is about 5 feet 10 inches high, of dark color, stammering address and quick movement, looks down when spoken to, and appears to laugh.
He had on when last seen gray shirt and pants and military cap. He has a scar near the line of his collar.
A reward of ten dollars will be given for his apprehension and delivery to me, or in jail.
He is probably in camp.
Miss E. A. Pilcher,
au 18--3t* Henrico.

div3.head: Five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my farm, in Henrico county, two miles from Richmond, on the 11th instant, a black negro boy, about fourteen years old, named Gilbert, hired from Dr. Duval, of Powhatan county.
The above reward will be paid on his delivery to me.
au 18--3t* James N. Shine.

div3.head: Two dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Thursday, the 14th inst., my nurse, Roberta, belonging to Mr. Greggory of Chesterfield.
The above reward will be paid for her delivery at my residence, or her whereabouts.
Levi Hexter,
au 18--3t* Corner Ross and Mayo sts.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to us of a negro boy named George, belonging to Mr. C. M. Ragland, of Scottsville.
Is about 16 years old, black and very likely, about five feet high.
He has been living in this city until recently, and his mother is hired to Mr. D. Ratcliffe, on Broad street, opposite Monumental Church.
au 14--4t* Ragland & Brother.

div3.head: Runaway in the army.
div3.p:
--My man George ran away the 1st day of February and probably joined our army, as it passed Gordonsville from Manassas to Richmond.
He was seen with an artillery company, having pack mules with it, passing from Fairfield into Richmond in May, and is doubtless passing as a free man, and may have changed to other kind of army service, or may be in the city, and most likely as cook or waiter.
He is 23 to 25 years old, black, neat, round features, weighs about 160 pounds, 5 feet 8 to 10 inches high, likely, and has a hoarse, confused manner of speech, and has probably changed his name.
I will give $100 for his delivery in jail, so that I get him again.
S. W. Ficklin.
jy 30--6t Charlottesville, Va.
